p: The mechanism by which the seed massâ€”seed number (SMSN) trade-off enables coexistence is still debated [ 36], but there is evidence for a range of relationships of seed mass with demographic rates. Small seeded species produce more seeds and gain a numerical advantage during colonisation [ 37], and also may disperse farther [ 38], thus reaching more sites. Large seeded species have been suggested to have higher emergence probability [ 28, 39, 40], seedling survival [ 41], seedling competitive ability [ 42, 43] or stress tolerance [ 44, 45].
